Van Buren ran for Governor of New York to boost Jackson's campaign. After serving as governor for two months, Van Buren resigned to become Jackson's Secretary of State. In 1831, Jackson gave Van Buren a recess appointment as American minister to Britain.
Camden, New Jersey is the home of Rutgers University -- Camden, which was founded as the South Jersey Law School in 1926, and Cooper Medical School of Rowan University, which opened in 2012.

Michigan is a state in the Great Lakes and Midwestern regions of the United States. Michigan is the tenth most populous of the 50 United States, with the 11th most extensive total area. Michigan is the only state to consist of two peninsulas. A U.S. state is a constituent political entity of the United States of America.

Penguin Books revolutionized publishing in the 1930s through its inexpensive paperbacks, sold through Woolworths and other high street stores for sixpence, bringing high-quality paperback fiction and non-fiction to the mass market.
Production took place in Sydney, Darwin, Kununurra, and Bowen.

Billy Ray Cyrus is an American country music singer, songwriter, actor and philanthropist. Excuse My French is the debut studio album by American rapper French Montana. Excuse My French is a 2014 Egyptian film Comedy directed by Amr Salama. The film was initially deemed too sensitive by the censorship board.
In 2013, Derek Hough starred in Make Your Move, a Romeo and Juliet-inspired South Korean-American independent dance film.

"Bad Romance" is a song by Lady Gaga from her third extended play, The Fame Monster (2009). It achieved worldwide success by topping the charts in a variety of markets, ultimately selling 12 million copies worldwide. "Bad Romance (film)" is a 2011 independent drama film.

DreamWorks Animation has released 34 feature films, including the franchises Shrek, Puss in Boots, Madagascar, Kung Fu Panda, How to Train Your Dragon, and Trolls, and other hits including Monsters vs. Aliens (2009), Rise of the Guardians (2012), The Croods (2013) and Home (2015). Trollhunters is an American computer-animated fantasy television series created for Netflix by Guillermo del Toro and produced by DreamWorks Animation and Double Dare You.

Chris Eubank, born August 8, 1966, is a British former professional boxer who competed from 1985 to 1998. Christopher Livingstone "Chris" Eubank Jr., born September 18, 1989, is a British professional boxer. He has held the IBO super-middleweight title since February 2017, the WBA interim middleweight title in 2015, and the British middleweight title in 2016. As of May 2017, Eubank Jr. is ranked as the world's fifth best super middleweight by BoxRec, seventh best middleweight by The Ring magazine, and eighth by the Transnational Boxing Rankings Board.

Sophia Anna Bush (born July 8, 1982) is an American actress, director, spokesperson, and activist. She is known for her film roles in John Tucker Must Die (2006), The Hitcher (2007), and The Narrows (2008).

Rupert Murdoch is the current chairman and acting CEO of Fox News. James Rupert Jacob Murdoch is an Australian, British, American businessman, the younger son of media mogul Rupert Murdoch, the chief executive officer (CEO) of 21st Century Fox, and chairman of Sky plc. Rupert Murdoch had full control as Chairman and CEO of global media holding company News Corporation, now the world's second-largest media conglomerate, and its successors, News Corp and 21st Century Fox, after the conglomerate split on 28 June 2013.

In 2013, Gal Gadot was ranked as the second highest earning actress/models in Israel, behind Bar Refaeli, but ahead of Esti Ginzburg and Shlomit Malka, with the majority of her income coming from acting.
Creedence Clearwater Revival, often informally abbreviated to Creedence or CCR, was an American rock band active in the late 1960s and early 1970s.
Calcaneal spurs are detected by a radiographic examination (commonly referred to as an "x-ray").
The South Wales Coalfield is a large region of south Wales that is rich in coal deposits, especially the South Wales Valleys.

The CONCACAF Champions League is an annual football club competition organized by CONCACAF for the top football clubs in North America, Central America and the Caribbean. The competition was originally known as the CONCACAF Champions' Cup when it was first organized in 1962.

Mary of Teck became queen mother after George's death in 1936. Her son Edward abdicated the throne. She supported her second son, Albert, who became George VI. She died in 1953 during the reign of her granddaughter Queen Elizabeth II.

The NAACP Image Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Drama Series was first given during the 1996 ceremony. Omar Epps and Joe Morton hold the record for the most wins with three each.

Human trafficking is the trade of humans for forced labor, sexual slavery, or commercial sexual exploitation. Forced labor generates an estimated $150 billion in profits per annum as of 2014. Of those exploited, 14.2 million were exploited for labor, 4.5 million were sexually exploited, and 2.2 million were exploited in state-imposed forced labor.
Rio (2011 film). A sequel, Rio 2, was released on April 11, 2014.

Francis I (Franz Stefan, François Étienne 8 December 1708 -- 18 August 1765) was Holy Roman Emperor and Grand Duke of Tuscany. Francis I (François Ier) (12 September 1494 -- 31 March 1547) was the first King of France from the Angoulême branch of the House of Valois, reigning from 1515 until his death. The Italian war of 1536-1538 was a conflict between King Francis I of France and Charles V, King of Spain and Holy Roman Emperor.

Peking University (PKU) is a major Chinese research university located in Beijing and a member of the C9 League. It is the first modern national university established in China, founded in 1898 as the Imperial University of Peking. It also served as the highest administration for education in China at the beginning of its founding. Peking University is ranked as the top higher learning institution in mainland China.
Lemmy was known for his appearance, including his friendly mutton chops, his distinctive gravelly voice and distinctive bass playing style.
Global warming threatens food security from decreasing crop yields and causes the abandonment of populated areas due to rising sea levels.

Australia is a 2008 Australian-American-British romantic historical adventure drama film directed by Baz Luhrmann and starring Nicole Kidman and Hugh Jackman. Baz Luhrmann's 2008 film Australia stars Hugh Jackman and Nicole Kidman.

Michael Dwayne Vick (born June 26, 1980) is a former American football quarterback who played 13 seasons in the National Football League, primarily with the Atlanta Falcons and the Philadelphia Eagles.

Canadian folklore includes songs, legends, jokes, rhymes, proverbs, weather lore, superstitions, and practices such as traditional food-making and craft-making. Folklore includes oral traditions such as tales, proverbs and jokes.
The First Motion Picture Unit produced over 400 propaganda and training films that were informative and entertaining. The unit also produced training films and trained combat cameramen.

James Jones (author) won the 1952 National Book Award for his first published novel, From Here to Eternity. James Jones (basketball player) averaged 25 points per game as a senior, earning Class 6A Player of the Year and First Team All-State honors. In 1999, the American Film Institute ranked Humphrey Bogart as the greatest male star of Classic American cinema.

In 2009, Shane McMahon announced his resignation from WWE which went into effect January 1, 2010.

Tom Baker is an English actor known for his portrayal of the fourth incarnation of the Doctor in the science fiction series Doctor Who from 1974 to 1981, and for the narration of the comedy series Little Britain. Baker has narrated commercials, video games, audiobooks and television series.
Angelsberg is a small town in the commune of Fischbach, in central Luxembourg.

Hanford Site hosts a commercial nuclear power plant, the Columbia Generating Station, and various centers for scientific research and development, such as the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory and the LIGO Hanford Observatory.

The White House Press Secretary is a senior White House official who acts as spokesperson for the executive branch of the United States government. The press secretary serves by the appointment of and at the pleasure of the president.

Kentucky is known as the "Bluegrass State". The Bluegrass Region in central Kentucky houses Louisville and Lexington. Kentucky is known for horse racing, bourbon distilleries, coal, My Old Kentucky Home, automobile manufacturing, tobacco, bluegrass music, college basketball, and Kentucky Fried Chicken.
Broken Bridges is a 2006 film starring Toby Keith, Lindsey Haun, Burt Reynolds and Kelly Preston. Kelly Preston also starred in the films The Cat in the Hat and Old Dogs.
Kesha Rose Sebert (born March 1, 1987; formerly stylized as Ke $ ha) is an American singer, songwriter, and rapper.
On May 5, 2017, an electronic version produced by American trio Major Lazer and Colombian DJ MOSKA and an urban version produced by Sky were released.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event held from 1983 to 2000 by the National Wrestling Alliance (NWA) and later World Championship Wrestling (WCW). In 1987, Starrcade was broadcast on pay-per-view, the first NWA event to do so. In 2014, the WWE Network included the previous Starrcades (1983 -- 1986), which had been transmitted via closed-circuit television, alongside the rest of the Starrcades in the pay-per-view section. Starrcade (1997) was the fifteenth annual Starrcade professional wrestling pay-per-view (PPV) event.
Veeru Devgan is an Indian stunt and action choreographer and film director in Bollywood.
Star Trek: Discovery is the first series developed specifically for that service, and the first Star Trek series since Star Trek: Enterprise concluded in 2005.

Terry Crews played as a defensive end and linebacker in the National Football League (NFL) for the Los Angeles Rams, San Diego Chargers and Washington Redskins, as well as in the World League of American Football with Rhein Fire.

Excuse My French is the debut studio album by American rapper French Montana. Excuse My French is a 2014 Egyptian film Comedy directed by Amr Salama. Benjamin Paul Ballance-Drew (born 22 October 1983), primarily known as Plan B or Ben Drew, is a British hip hop recording artist, actor, film director and producer.

A floppy disk is a type of disk storage composed of a disk of thin and flexible magnetic storage medium, sealed in a rectangular plastic enclosure lined with fabric that removes dust particles. A floppy disk is a disk storage medium composed of a disk of thin and flexible magnetic storage medium encased in a rectangular plastic carrier.

From the mid to late 19th century, Guatemala experienced chronic instability and civil strife. From 1960 to 1996, Guatemala endured a bloody civil war fought between the US-backed government and leftist rebels, including genocidal massacres of the Maya population perpetrated by the military.
Forceps are a handheld, hinged instrument used for grasping and holding objects. Outside medicine, people usually refer to forceps as tweezers, tongs, pliers, clips or clamps.
On Monday, July 11, 2011, the series began its seventh and final season, having finished its sixth season as cable's highest rated drama.

Dr. Jack Shephard is a fictional character and the protagonist of the ABC television series Lost, played by Matthew Fox. Lost is an American television drama series that originally aired on ABC from September 22, 2004, to May 23, 2010, over six seasons, comprising a total of 121 episodes. The first season garnered an estimated average of 16 million viewers per episode on ABC.

Matthew David McConaughey, born November 4, 1969, is an American actor. Since 2011 he has preferred dramatic roles. Mud (2012 film) stars Matthew McConaughey, Tye Sheridan, Jacob Lofland, Sam Shepard, and Reese Witherspoon.
Robert Palmer is best known for his books, music journalism, work producing blues recordings and the soundtrack of the film Deep Blues, and his clarinet playing in the 1960s band the Insect Trust.

James Lincoln de la Mothe Borglum (April 9, 1912 - January 27, 1986) was an American sculptor, photographer, author, and engineer. He was best known for overseeing the completion of the Mount Rushmore National Memorial after the death in 1941 of the project's leader, his father, Gutzon Borglum. Gutzon Borglum created the sculpture's design and oversaw the project's execution from 1927-1941 with the help of his son, Lincoln Borglum. Upon Gutzon Borglum's death in March 1941, his son Lincoln Borglum took over as leader of the construction project.

The film Underdog was directed by Frederik Du Chau and written by Joe Piscatella, Adam Rifkin, and Craig A. Williams. The film stars Jim Belushi, Peter Dinklage, John Slattery, and Patrick Warburton with the voice talents of Jason Lee, Amy Adams, and Brad Garrett.

The 100 (TV series) follows a group of teens: Clarke Griffin (Eliza Taylor), Bellamy Blake (Bob Morley), Octavia Blake (Marie Avgeropoulos), Jasper Jordan (Devon Bostick), Monty Green (Christopher Larkin), Raven Reyes (Lindsey Morgan), Finn Collins (Thomas McDonell), John Murphy (Richard Harmon), and Wells Jaha (Eli Goree) as they are among the first people from a space habitat, ``The Ark'', to return to Earth after a devastating nuclear apocalypse; the series also focuses on Dr. Abby Griffin (Paige Turco), Clarke's mother; Marcus Kane (Henry Ian Cusick), a council member on the Ark; and Thelonious Jaha (Isaiah Washington), the Chancellor of the Ark and Wells' father.

The Concert for Bangladesh is recognized as a highly successful and influential humanitarian aid project, generating awareness and considerable funds. It provided valuable lessons and inspiration for projects that followed, notably Live Aid. The project was marred by financial problems.
Mani Ratnam is one of India's influential filmmakers. He is credited with revolutionizing the Tamil film industry and altering the profile of Indian cinema.

The Freeport Doctrine was articulated by Stephen A. Douglas on August 27, 1858, in Freeport, Illinois. The Lincoln-Douglas Debates were a series of seven debates between Abraham Lincoln and Stephen Douglas. The debates in Freeport, Quincy and Alton drew large numbers of people from neighboring states.

Easy A is a 2010 American teen comedy film directed by Will Gluck, written by Bert V. Royal and starring Emma Stone, Stanley Tucci, Patricia Clarkson, Thomas Haden Church, Dan Byrd, Amanda Bynes, Penn Badgley, Cam Gigandet, Lisa Kudrow and Aly Michalka.

Anne Rice (born October 4, 1941) is an American author of gothic fiction, Christian literature, and erotica. She began her professional writing career with the publication of Interview with the Vampire in 1976. She became more popular with critics and readers in the 1980s. She was married to Stan Rice for 41 years, from 1961 until his death in 2002.

Camden is a city in Camden County, New Jersey. At the 2010 United States Census, the city had a population of 77,344. Camden is the 12th most populous municipality in New Jersey. At the beginning of the twentieth century Camden's population consisted mostly of European immigrants. A city is a large and permanent human settlement.
Bret Easton Ellis wrote the screenplay for the 2013 film The Canyons. The Canyons is a 2013 American erotic thriller-drama film directed by Paul Schrader and written by Bret Easton Ellis.

The Lincoln -- Douglas Debates ( also known as The Great Debates of 1858 ) were a series of seven debates between Abraham Lincoln and Stephen Douglas. The debates were held in seven towns in the state of Illinois.
Homer is the name ascribed by the ancient Greeks to the author of the Iliad and the Odyssey. The Thicket is a mystery/suspense novel written by American author Joe R. Lansdale.
Christopher Scott Kyle was a United States Navy SEAL veteran and sniper. On February 2, 2013, Kyle was murdered by Eddie Ray Routh at a shooting range near Chalk Mountain, Texas.

Audioslave was a four-piece band with Chris Cornell, Tom Morello, Tim Commerford, and Brad Wilk. Brad Wilk is known as the drummer of Rage Against the Machine and Audioslave. Rage Against the Machine was formed in 1991 and consists of Zack de la Rocha, Tim Commerford, Tom Morello, and Brad Wilk.

Janelle Monáe Robinson (born December 1, 1985) is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model signed to Wondaland Arts Society and Atlantic Records. In 2010, Monáe released her first full-length studio album, The ArchAndroid, which was released by Bad Boy Records.
Winter's Tale is a 1983 novel by Mark Helprin.

Lake Providence is a town in and the parish seat of East Carroll Parish in northeastern Louisiana, United States. About 55 percent of its undergraduates and 60 percent overall come from Mississippi, and 23 percent are minorities; international students come from 90 nations.

Aaron Burr was elected twice to the New York State Assembly (1784-1785, 1798-1799), was appointed New York State Attorney General (1789-1791), was chosen as a U.S. senator (1791-1797) from the State of New York, and reached the apex of his career as vice president.

Soyuz is a series of spacecraft designed for the Soviet space program by the Korolyov Design Bureau in the 1960s that remains in service today. It was commissioned to launch Soyuz spacecraft as part of the Soviet human spaceflight program, first with 8 unmanned test flights, followed by the first 19 manned launches. The Soyuz succeeded the Voskhod spacecraft and was originally built as part of the Soviet manned lunar programs.
Steve Ditko studied under Batman artist Jerry Robinson at the Cartoonist and Illustrators School in New York City.

Rage Against the Machine broke up due to tensions in the band, and de la Rocha started a solo career. The rest of the band formed Audioslave with Chris Cornell. Rage Against the Machine announced a reunion in 2007. Renegades is the fourth studio album by Rage Against the Machine, released on December 5, 2000.

The S&P BSE SENSEX, also called the BSE 30 or simply the SENSEX, is a free-float market-weighted stock market index of 30 well-established and financially sound companies listed on Bombay Stock Exchange. Tata Motors is listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange, where it is a constituent of the BSE SENSEX index, the National Stock Exchange of India, and the New York Stock Exchange.

Vietnam, officially the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, is the easternmost country on the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia. It has an estimated 92.7 million inhabitants, making it the world's 14th-most-populous country. Vietnam is bordered by China, Laos, Cambodia, Thailand, the Philippines, Malaysia and Indonesia. Since 2000, Vietnam's economic growth rate has been among the highest in the world. Vietnam remains one of the world's four remaining one-party socialist states officially espousing communism.
Dreamer is a 2005 American sports drama film written and directed by John Gatins in his directorial debut.

Bhagat Singh (March 23, 1931) was an Indian socialist revolutionary whose acts of violence against the British in India and execution at age 23 made him a folk hero of the Indian independence movement. Bhagat Singh became a popular folk hero after his death.
Aparshakti Khurana made his Bollywood debut with Aamir Khan's ``Dangal''. Dangal is a 2016 Indian Hindi-language biographical sports drama film directed by Nitesh Tiwari.

James VI and I was King of Scotland as James VI from 24 July 1567 and King of England and Ireland as James I from 24 March 1603 until his death. The kingdoms of Scotland and England were individual sovereign states, though both were ruled by James in personal union. He was a major advocate of a single parliament for England and Scotland. James VI and I faced many difficulties with Parliament during his reign in England.

Danielle Cormack (born 26 December 1970) is a stage and screen actress from New Zealand. She was one of the original core cast of the soap opera Shortland Street. She is also known for her role as the Amazon Ephiny in the television series Xena: Warrior Princess, Cynthia Ross in The Cult, and Shota in Legend of the Seeker. Her most notable work in recent years was her portrayal of Bea Smith in the Foxtel prison drama Wentworth, in which she starred for four years before leaving the show in 2016.
Rob Sheridan (born October 11, 1979) is an American graphic designer, director, and photographer best known for his work with the band Nine Inch Nails.

David Spade starred and co-starred in the films Tommy Boy, Black Sheep, Joe Dirt, Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser, Grown Ups, and Grown Ups 2, among others. Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser is a 2015 American comedy film directed by Fred Wolf and written by David Spade and Fred Wolf.
Angela Evelyn Bassett (born August 16, 1958) is an American actress.

Artpop received mixed reviews but was commercially successful, debuting at number one on the United States Billboard 200 with first-week sales of 258,000 copies. It was Gaga's second consecutive number-one record in the United States and sold 757,000 copies. Artpop was the ninth best-selling album of 2013 with 2.3 million copies worldwide.

2006 saw the release of John Frusciante's fifth and final album with the Chili Peppers, Stadium Arcadium. The album is also the group's last to feature guitarist John Frusciante, who confirmed his departure from the band in 2009.

Margaret Thatcher was Prime Minister and implemented policies known as Thatcherism. She was a controversial figure and has been lauded as one of the greatest and most influential politicians in British history.

Michael Andrew `` Duff '' McKagan (born February 5, 1964) is an American musician, singer, songwriter and author. He has written weekly columns on a wide variety of topics for SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com, and ESPN.com.
Tom Baker is an English actor. He has narrated commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.

Valencia is the capital of the autonomous community of Valencia and the third largest city in Spain after Madrid and Barcelona, with around 800,000 inhabitants in the administrative centre. Valencia is Spain's third largest metropolitan area, with a population ranging from 1.7 to 2.5 million. The Valencian Community is an autonomous community of Spain. Its homonymous capital Valencia is the third largest city and metropolitan area in Spain.
Buffy Summers was portrayed by Kristy Swanson in the film and by Sarah Michelle Gellar in the television series.
The series "Make It or Break It" ended and the third season was the final season. The series finale aired on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition is a sub-field of computational linguistics that develops technologies that enable the recognition and translation of spoken language into text by computers. Speech recognition applications include voice user interfaces such as voice dialing, call routing, domotic appliance control, search, simple data entry, preparation of structured documents, speech-to-text processing, and aircraft. The worldwide industry adoption of deep learning methods in designing and deploying speech recognition systems is evidence of advances in the field.

Richard Alf (January 26, 1952 -- January 4, 2012) was an American businessman and former comic book store owner who co-founded the San Diego Comic-Con International and served as its chairman beginning in 1970. San Diego Comic-Con was founded as the Golden State Comic Book Convention in 1970 by a group of San Diegans that included Shel Dorf, Richard Alf, Ken Krueger and Mike Towry. It was later called the `` San Diego Comic Book Convention ''.
Fist of Legend is a remake of the 1972 Fist of Fury, which starred Bruce Lee.

Dubuisson carded a 67 to tie with Van Zyl on 16 under par. McIlroy carded a third straight five under-par 67 to move to 15 under par with Aphibarnrat. McIlroy's round included an eagle on the 12th. McIlroy was level par for the day after 10 holes, but hit back with a birdie on the par-five 11th and an eagle on the 13th. He ruptured a ligament in his left ankle in July. He is targeting a third Race to Dubai title in four years and leads Willett by 271,214 points with three events remaining after the Turkish Open. Wood (-13) and Bland (-12) are fifth and seventh respectively.

Sheikh Ali Salman told the BBC that for national dialogue to be meaningful, the government had to show its willingness to offer "concrete solutions". Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa is seen as a reformist. Hardliners are said to be opposed to a dialogue process. Sheikh Salman insisted that now was the time for dialogue. The al-Wefaq leader acknowledged that many young protesters had lost faith in the main opposition parties. Sheikh Salman noted that hours before King Hamad brought in Gulf Co-operation Council (GCC) troops to restore order and crush dissent on 14 March 2011, the crown prince and opposition had agreed a seven-point plan that would have moved Bahrain towards a constitutional monarchy. Sheikh Salman said he was "hopeful" that Senator John Kerry would "do more than his predecessor", Hillary Clinton. The al-Wefaq leader said that the UK government needs to speak out publically. Sheikh Salman also reiterated al-Wefaq's position that it would continue to call for "peaceful demonstrations". He also called for the release of 13 opposition leaders and human rights activists.

Christopher Hogwood died at his home in Cambridge following an illness lasting several months. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service to be held at a later date. He founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973 and directed the academy across six continents for some 30 years. The AAM made more than 200 CDs. He studied keyboard at Cambridge University and his first positions were as a keyboard player and musicologist with the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields. He was the artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society. He was also a tutor at Harvard University, honorary professor of music at the University of Cambridge and a professor-at-large at Cornell University in the US.

In the year to the end of March, 57 homicide victims were recorded, which is down five from the previous 12 months. This is the lowest number of recorded homicide cases for a single 12-month period since 1976. A sharp instrument remained the most common method of killing in Scotland and accounted for 51% of homicides (29 cases) in 2015-16. 31% (20 people) of the accused were identified by the police as being under the influence of alcohol or alcohol and drugs.
Bournemouth lost 2-1 to Sunderland. Dan Gosling scored Bournemouth's first goal in three games. Bournemouth had enough chances to win three games.

Mr. Abbott said the only way to prevent people dying at sea was to "stop the boats". Australia detains migrants trying to reach its shores by boat and takes them to offshore processing camps. The New York Times described the policy as "brutal" and "inhumane". Mr. Abbott said the image of Alan Kurdi was "very sad" and that Australia has stopped illegal boats. Mr. Abbott angered Australian Jewish groups by saying IS was worse than the Nazis. The Executive Council of Australian Jewry said the comment was "injudicious and unfortunate". Mr. Abbott later said he stood by his comments.

Washington blamed Russia and the Syrian government for intensifying their attacks against civilians. The US warned it would halt the talks unless Moscow stops bombing the city of Aleppo. Russia said it regretted the US move, accusing it of shifting the blame for the collapse of last month's truce. The US is suspending its participation in bilateral channels with Russia. Moscow and Syrian President Bashar al-Assad's troops had been "targeting of critical infrastructure such as hospitals, and preventing humanitarian aid from reaching civilians in need. The two sides would keep talking about counter-terrorism operations in Syria to avoid unnecessary clashes.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, 25, died last week at his home in Swansea, the city at the centre of an epidemic of measles which has reached 942 cases. An inquest will be opened and adjourned on Tuesday to allow further tests to determine the cause of death. Since the outbreak began in November, 83 people have needed hospital treatment for the illness. Mr Colfer-Williams had recently been treated at Swansea's Morriston Hospital for asthma. Laboratory tests confirmed a diagnosis of measles but further tests were needed to determine the cause of death.

Vincent Hudson has been charged with a historical offence on a boy under the age of 16. The attack was reported to have taken place in 2001. Mr. Hudson, 54, of Loweswater Avenue, Whitehaven, is due to appear before North Cumbria Magistrates' Court later.
Gateshead and Guiseley tied 1-1. Guiseley scored first with Jake Lawlor scoring on 15 minutes. Wes York scored for Gateshead on 62 minutes.

Bristol Sport Ltd wants to replace two stands to increase capacity. The work was approved by Bristol City Council in November. If there is no judicial review by March, the redevelopment plans will begin in May.

Cuadrilla suspended drilling after a 1.5 magnitude tremor, the second in two months. The British Geological Survey (BGS) will examine the data collected before deciding whether to resume. A tremor on 1 April shared a "similar location and mechanism". The BGS is also monitoring fracking as a precaution. There have been two small earthquakes in Lancashire since fracking began in March. The April tremor took place 1.2 miles (2km) away from the drilling site. The earthquake was felt by at least one person in Poulton-Le-Fylde. The event occurred at a depth of approximately 2km (1.2 miles).

Angus Carpenter, 62, denied three counts of fraud. He was found guilty of one count when he played with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner on his bagpipes in April 2015. He was cleared of the two other counts. Carpenter said he was simply busking. He will be sentenced in January.

Ipswich Town defeated Queens Park Rangers 
3-0. Grant Ward's shot put Town ahead, and Luke Varney scored after QPR keeper Alex Smithies miscued a clearance. Tom Lawrence capped the scoring with a calm finish. Rangers offered little in attack, but sub Sandro headed Tjarron Cherry's corner against the post. The win lifted Mick McCarthy's Ipswich up four places to 14th and above Rangers.

Wells, 23, scored 373 runs at 28.69 with a strike rate of 138.66 in the T20 Blast last season. Wells said the club is going in the right direction and the environment created by the coaches is of elite performance.
The Reds beat Chinnor 29-12 for a second win in a row. The Reds face seven teams who are below them in the table in their next eight games, as well as league leaders Old Elthamians.

Nazrul, also called Nazu, was arrested at a railway station in Kolkata. He is alleged to have raped the 74-year-old nun. This marks the sixth arrest in the crime. Police have identified eight suspects in the attack, of which two still remain untraced. All five accused arrested earlier have named Nazrul as the person who raped the nun. During the attack in Ranaghat town on 14 March, money was stolen from the convent school and the building ransacked, before the nun was raped in the convent itself.

Robert Opie, the founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising in London, outlines some of the main reasons why we change what we buy in this interactive video. The arrival of the domestic freezer, of washing powder, and of cheaper imports all affected the sort of items on sale and popular among UK consumers. The interactive elements to this video also explore how ownership and ranking of some of the biggest brands in the UK is changing.

A 71-year-old woman from Sandyhills was tricked by someone claiming to work for BT. A woman in Stranraer lost money to a caller who said he was contacting her about problems with her internet. The caller claimed to be from BT technical support and gained remote access to her computer to take the cash. The Sandyhills incident happened on 15 September with the Stranraer con taking place seven days later. People should never give out any banking details or account numbers over the telephone.

Duffy, 37, has joined Featherstone on a one-year contract after leaving Swinton Lions. The Scotland assistant coach will lead Featherstone in their final league game against Toulouse on Saturday before the upcoming Super 8 Qualifiers. Duffy played for Leigh, Widnes and Salford during a 16-year playing career.

A Porthcawl RNLI crew, a medic, and the coastguard search and rescue helicopter were sent to Sker Beach at 12:50 GMT on Sunday. The rider had head injuries and was very cold. She was treated before being flown to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales.

A UN conference in Geneva decided to dedicate part of the radio spectrum to a global flight tracking system. The conference was organized by the UN's International Telecommunication Union (ITU). Representatives from more than 160 countries decided to set aside a radio frequency for the satellite tracking of planes at the World Radiocommunication Conference (WRC). The deal will enable satellites to receive transmissions, known as automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast (ADS-B), that aircraft currently only send to other aircraft and to ground stations. The UN's aviation arm, the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO), has set a November 2016 deadline for adopting new tracking guidelines.

Julian Hernandez disappeared when he was five and is now 18, living with his father in Cleveland. Bobby Hernandez, 53, was arrested and is being held at a jail in Ohio. The FBI received a tip on 30 October that this teenager may be the long-missing child. His father is also charged with tampering with records in Ohio so he could obtain a driver's licence in 2012. He is being held at the Cuyahoga County Jail in Ohio with a $250,000 bail.

Firefighters were at the site in Duncan Street for several days following the blaze on 2 March, which reduced train services and caused travel delays. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste after the fire. The firm was "broadly compliant" with fire safety law, the fire service said. Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited, whose site was run by Asset and Land Group, could not be contacted for a comment. It has until 7 August to appeal the decision. The fire service raised concerns to the EA in February over the impact a fire could have on nearby residents, transport and the environment. The EA has decided to revoke the environmental permit, subject to any appeal, the revocation takes effect on 7 August, which means after that date the company will no longer be able to operate from that site. The company is still required to remove all the waste. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

A Just Russia put forward bills linked to the situation in Ukraine. Russian MPs say a referendum or a plea from a territory's leaders would be enough to trigger the new provisions. One bill would speed up the procedures for issuing Russian passports. The bill would allow Ukrainians to apply for Russian passports at Russian diplomatic missions before 1 August, and they could become citizens after two months.

Thomas Baker, 44, from Everton, was found badly injured at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool on 27 January. He had been shot in the head and chest and died later in hospital. Three Liverpool men were arrested and remain in police custody for questioning. Mr. Baker had left Phoenix Gym at the market shortly before he was shot. Detectives are searching for a silver VW polo that left the scene at speed.

Here is a summary of the passage:
*   Everyday Church Online runs virtual services every Sunday.
*   The first Christmas theme is Star Wars.
*   Guardians of Ancora is a free-play game for children.
*   The Digital Story of Nativity is a video that has been viewed almost six million times.
*   The Churches Advertising Network had a video called Christmas Starts with a Baby's Giggle.
*   Next Manga has launched its work in app and e-book form.

An eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale is examining the request to take over 250 hectares (600 acres) of common land. Backers have offered around 320 hectares (800 acres) replacement land. The inquiry has heard conflicting accounts from experts over claims the circuit would damage habitats and plant life by building on the common land. Natural Resources Wales said it was "difficult to conclude" that the replacement land was of equal value, but it was not opposing the development overall. An ecology report presented by the developers said there would be a "net gain" in biodiversity because the plans included work to enhance other habitats nearby - which the Gwent wildlife trust argued against. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will make a recommendation after the inquiry in Ebbw vale, before Welsh government ministers have the final say on whether the plans can go ahead.

On April 3, Chechen Muslim clerics met and said a report had insulted their faith and the dignity of Chechen men. Novaya Gazeta says it amounts to a call for "reprisals against journalists". On April 1, the paper reported that more than 100 people had been detained in Chechnya on suspicion of being homosexual, and that at least three had been killed. The Russian LGBT Network said the report was true. Detainees were tortured with electric shocks and beatings at a prison near Argun. Ramzan Kadyrov has denied the allegations, calling them "lies". The Chechens' spiritual leader, Mufti Salah-haji Mezhiev, confirmed that "retribution" was part of the resolution adopted at the special Muslim meeting. Novaya Gazeta's chief editor Dmitry Muratov said his journalists would continue investigating human rights abuses in Chechnya. The LGBT Network says it is helping people to flee the persecution in Chechnya and accuses the Russian authorities of ignoring the abuses.

Investing Solutions finds properties for single homeless men and receives housing benefit payments. Fresh Start Housing, a charity, finds clients from London homeless charities and refers them to Investing Solutions and private landlords. Investing Solutions makes money by charging housing benefit for each person in a house, resulting in a higher payout than the rent fee. Both companies are based in the same building and were set up by Samir Patel. Investing Solutions is one of the largest recipients of housing benefit in the UK. A tenant, Nigel McCann, described the properties as unsuitable. Wandsworth Council has paid Investing Solutions over £2.1m. A homeless charity says the relationship is "a new low".

Andrew Lawrence scored 14 points and Ben Gordon added 13. Coach Joe Prunty's team led for most of the first three quarters before being overhauled by their guests in the last 10 minutes. GB now begin their Eurobasket qualifying campaign with a game in Hungary in midweek. Netherlands, who were led by 18 points from Worthy De Jong, scored the first 10 points of the fourth quarter to lead 71-60 and held on to win despite the hosts' comeback in the last six minutes.

The Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) is debating whether to allow the fight between McGregor and Mayweather to use 8oz gloves instead of the required 10oz gloves for fights at 154 lbs. McGregor submitted a waiver to the NAC. The NAC will debate the matter publicly before announcing its decision. McGregor will make his boxing debut against Mayweather.

The Sunday Post is closing its London office. Fleet Street was once a very important place where most of the public received its information. The first British daily newspaper, the Daily Courant, was published in Fleet Street on March 11, 1702. The street was famous for its many bars and pubs. Gavin Sherriff worked on Fleet Street for 32 years and is taking time out to write his memoirs. Mr. Smith is becoming a freelance journalist.

The author of Harry Potter said that her "personal line [had] been crossed" by some abusive comments. Rowling faced criticism on Twitter after it emerged she had donated Â£1m to the campaign for a No vote in the Scottish independence referendum. She revealed she had been called "a traitor" for her political views and had blocked some abusive Twitter users she believed had been supporters of the Scottish National Party (SNP). The SNP took 56 of the 59 seats in Scotland in Thursday's election and is now the third largest party in the UK.

Children from deprived backgrounds were twice as likely to face police action than better-off children who commit the same crime. Living in poverty increased the likelihood of violence among both boys and girls. A history of being in trouble with the police was the strongest predictor of whether a young person was not in education, employment or training by the age of 18. Poorer young people were also about five times more likely to be placed on statutory supervision than their better-off counterparts. Household poverty increased the likelihood of young people offending. Boys were three times more likely than girls on average to engage in violent acts. Girls from poorer backgrounds were twice as likely as girls from more affluent households to be involved in violent crime. The study has tracked 4,300 young people in Edinburgh since 1998. The recent fall in crime rates in Scotland has not benefitted areas with the most chronic rates of crime. Crime tends to be highly concentrated amongst poor people and within poor neighborhoods. Scotland is becoming a safer place to live.

Mr. Haugh, 25, was stabbed in the Marian estate. Robbie Walsh was charged with assault causing serious harm to Mr. Haugh and was remanded in custody. Two other men were released without charge. Mr. Walsh was one of three people who entered the Marian Estate and called to houses looking for Mr. Haugh. A fight ensued where weapons were used, and Mr. Haugh received a stab wound to his back. Mr. Haugh was brought to Limerick University Hospital where he was pronounced dead. Police recovered a knife handle and a blade at the scene. Mr. Walsh was remanded in custody until 14 August.

Phil Flanagan tweeted about Tom Elliott after he appeared on a BBC radio program in May 2014. The tweet read "Tom Elliott speaks to Steven Nolan about past. "I wonder if he will reveal how many people he harassed and shot as a member of the UDR." Mr. Elliott served in the UDR for 10 years, between 1982 and 1992. The tweet was deleted by Mr. Flanagan within an hour of being posted. The apology will state that the Sinn Féin MLA accepts that his tweet about Mr. Elliott "was untrue and wholly without foundation". The insurance firm has refused to cover Mr. Flanagan in respect of any compensation and costs in this case. Mr. Elliott said: "I have been totally vindicated and Phil Flanagan has admitted that the comments he made were totally untrue.

Hawick Knitwear, which employs more than 230 staff, has increased its production of sweaters to meet demand. The company, which dates back to 1874, was bought by managing director Benny Hartop in November last year. Hawick Knitwear sells into Sweden, Finland, Ireland, Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium, France, Italy and Spain. Markets outside Europe include the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Japan. The knitwear firm has increased its production to 9,500 sweaters each week, from about 7,500 last year, to keep up with demand.

Sylvia Blackburn, 72, suffered serious head injuries outside Bedford Road Lower School. Brian Wright, 55, told Luton Crown Court he had been blinded by the setting sun and accepted he had struck Mrs. Blackburn but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. Mrs. Blackburn is now being treated in residential care. Mr. Wright's VW Golf failed to stop for a red light. Mrs. Blackburn, a lollipop lady for 20 years, stepped out to escort a woman and her six-year-old daughter across the road when the traffic lights turned red. The court heard the sun was 10 minutes from setting and could have been shining into Mr. Wright's eyes. The trial continues.

The exercise is a response to the growing threat from Russian submarines. The German U-boat U33 is acting as the unseen enemy below the waves. The exercise is a reminder of a significant gap in the UK's defenses. Britain no longer has any of its own maritime patrol aircraft.
