England won with a day to spare at Old Trafford to level the series. England made 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared. Joe Root was named man of the match after scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 off 48 balls in the second. Pakistan were bowled out for 234 on Monday. Pakistan play a two-day tour game against Worcestershire at New Road starting on Friday before the third Test at Edgbaston gets under way on 3 August.

Warren Gatland is leading the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand and has named interim coach Rob Howley as part of his backroom team. Forwards coach McBryde assumes head coach responsibilities for the third time. The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) will appoint assistant coaches for the summer tour to assist McBryde. The WRU hopes to confirm the full make-up of the management team next week. Union chairman Gareth Davies believes the involvement of Welsh coaches will benefit the national team.

Charlie Austin's penalty put Southampton in control, but Hull City won 2-1. Snodgrass scored a goal and assisted another. David Marshall made saves in the Hull goal. Hull's win ends a six-game losing streak.

The crash happened at about 14:15 BST on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa. A motorcyclist was killed in the collision. The tractor driver was not injured. The B1191 was closed in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction in Woodhall Spa and the A158 Jubilee Way junction in Horncastle.

President Ivanov cancelled an investigation into claims of abuse of power. His move was condemned by the opposition and by EU officials. Macedonia has been in turmoil since the recordings were released in 2015. The crisis was sparked by covert recordings which appear to show ministers plotting vote-rigging and the cover-up of a murder.

Curtis and Paul Williams will take charge of Saturday's match against Bournemouth after Bob Bradley's sacking. Swansea want to appoint their new boss as soon as possible, with ex-Derby manager Paul Clement the first choice. Curtis believes the current Swansea squad is good enough to stay up. Swansea were promoted to the Premier League in 2011.

The Daggers needed a victory to keep their survival hopes alive, but lost to Orient. Goals from Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona gave them hope after Jay Simpson fired the O's into a 2-0 lead, but Armand Gnanduillet fired in the winner to relegate Dagenham and keep Orient's play-off hopes alive. Dagenham reached League One in 2010 and the Football League for the first time in their history in 2007, but now return to the National League. John Still, the same manager who took the club from the Conference to League One, is committed to helping the Daggers gain promotion from the National League next season. Victory leaves Orient two points adrift of the play-off spots and comes four days after player-manager Kevin Nolan was removed from his managerial role.

Steven Gerrard, 36, is returning to his former club as a youth coach in February. This will be his first job since retiring as a player. Gerrard made his Liverpool debut in 1998 and left Anfield at the end of the 2014-15 season to join MLS side LA Galaxy. He retired as a player in November after a 19-year career. Gerrard is also working towards his Uefa A coaching license.
McManus opened the scoring and Ross Forbes doubled Morton's lead. Kyle McAusland scored for Alloa. McManus and Denny Johnstone scored for the hosts.

Ofsted found evidence of children being taught in squalid conditions in three places in Birmingham which have now closed. Anyone running illegal schools could face a jail term of up to 51 weeks. Ministers are consulting on plans for more regulation of places teaching for more than 6 to 8 hours a week. A total of 18 unregulated schools, mainly in Muslim communities in the Midlands, have been visited as part of an investigation in recent months. Three places in Birmingham have been closed and the owners are being investigated under suspicion of running an illegal school. Any place where children are taught for more than 20 hours a week has to register as a school. The government has provided funding for a team of six inspectors whose job will be to investigate illegal schools. The education secretary has now said she intends to prepare cases for prosecution against unregistered schools it has identified. The government consultation on further regulation runs until mid-January.

Lilliard Gin is based at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh. The gin distillery is a natural companion to the Scottish Borders Brewery on the site. Lilliard Gin aims to capture the local flavor palette and Borders 'terroir'. The gin takes its name from a legendary Borders figure.

Gary Green, 51, reversed a vehicle into Harry Whitlam at Swithens Farm in August 2013, and Whitlam died. Green was more than two times the legal driving limit. Green had consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer before going to bed at 02:00 BST. Green was jailed for 16 months and two weeks. He had previously admitted failing to ensure the safety of others. He was prosecuted under health and safety legislation.

Luis Suarez, 27, can now train and play in friendly matches. Barcelona confirmed he will join the first team's training session on Friday and the public presentation of Suarez as a new Barcelona player will be held on Monday. He will still have to serve the remaining eight games of his record nine-match ban in competitive international games. His competitive Barcelona debut is likely to be at Real Madrid on 26 October. Suarez will now be available for Uruguay's friendlies against Japan and South Korea in September and Saudi Arabia the following month. The Cas ruling prevents him from playing "organised" matches but now allows him to take part in all "football-related activities".

Richard Blake-Smith and Anna beat Vytautas Kirkliauskas of Lithuania, carrying his wife, Neringa Kirliauskiene. Competitors must tackle a 380-metre course, hurdling over haystacks, scrabbling up a steep slope, and dodging water pistols. Rich and Anna will now compete at the World Championships in Finland in July.

Job roles will change when the paper system for car tax discs is scrapped in October. The tax disc would be replaced with an electronic system in October 2014. The new system will allow people to pay the charge by monthly direct debit. Any reductions in numbers of people needed for these activities will be managed through redeploying to other growth areas of the business.

The EU objects to Hungary's tight controls on asylum seekers and non-governmental organisations (NGOs), as well as a higher education law. Critics say the education law could lead to the closure of the prestigious Central European University. Thousands of Hungarians have held protest rallies against the laws in recent months. Hungary will not backtrack on any of the three issues. Poland would veto any move to strip Hungary of its EU voting rights. Hungary is currently forcibly housing asylum seekers in secured shipping containers. Hungary's Higher Education Law, signed in April, could force the closure of the Budapest-based CEU. Draft legislation on NGOs is expected to go before parliament soon.

The film will be released in US cinemas on 17 March 2017. Emma Watson will play Belle. Dan Stevens will play the Beast and Luke Evans will co-star as the villainous Gaston. Josh Gad will play Gaston's sidekick LeFou. Bill Condon will direct the movie, which begins filming at Shepperton Studios in May.

Adrian Gill, a columnist for the Sunday Times, died of cancer. He was diagnosed with "an embarrassment of cancer, the full English" of cancers. He was a giant among journalists. He was a "giant among journalists". He was also the "heart and soul" of the paper. He joined in 93. He was born in 1954. He was married to Cressida Connolly in 
1983. He was married to current Home Secretary Amber Rudd. He was married to in 1991. He was married to current Home Secretary Amber Rudd, in 1991. He was married to current Home Secretary, Amber Rudd, in 1991.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, a rapper, was allegedly attacked in Ulan Bator. Russian news reported he was hit with a bottle and kicked in the face. The Russian embassy said it was investigating and called local press reports "distorted". The rapper wore a Mongolian robe with a swastika, a traditional symbol in Mongolia. His father said he spent about 10 days in a coma. The Russian official accused of attacking the rapper has not been identified. The Russian embassy said reports were "distorted". The musician's lawyer, father, and a band member denied reports that he shouted "Heil Hitler" at the show. A police spokesman said the case was under investigation and the suspect is a Russian diplomatic officer.

Campaigners from action group Plane Stupid staged a demonstration on Monday in opposition to the airport's expansion plans. The men and women have been charged with aggravated trespass and entering a security restricted area of an aerodrome. They will appear in court on 19 August. The protest took place on the northern runway at 03:30 BST on Monday. The Metropolitan Police said security at the airport would be reviewed.

Nick Selman scored 101 off 144 balls, his second first-class century. Matt Taylor and Craig Miles made sure wickets fell at regular intervals. Aneurin Donald scored 36 off 30 balls. Graham Wagg and Timm van der Gugten scrambled Glamorgan to a consolation bonus point. Glamorgan is being led by Michael Hogan for the first time in the absence of Jacques Rudolph, who has a neck problem.

Craig Hughes, 33, was arrested by North Wales Police in August after chatting online with the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee. Hughes admitted two charges at Mold Crown Court on Friday and will be sentenced next week. Hughes said he was planning to make a false report to the police so that officers would come to the scene and he would then shoot them on the Dee Estuary. The threats were made on two occasions, late at night, while Hughes was drunk. Judge Niclas Parry remanded him in custody pending sentence. Hughes had a previous conviction for possessing a firearm in 2009. North Wales Police was particularly concerned because the defendant was on bail, awaiting trial for firearms offences, of which he was subsequently cleared. The Hope Line centre offers confidential support and counselling to people experiencing difficulty.

After being reduced to 8-2, they posted a score of 255-7, with Davies and Ben Foakes (90) sharing a stand of 130. Yorkshire's run-chase was undermined by a three-wicket burst in nine balls from Stuart Meaker. Tim Bresnan made 68 but was the last to go as they were all out for 236. Yorkshire were hoping to atone by reaching Lord's for the first time since 2002. Davies went on to hit a six and 10 fours before finally falling to Waite, who took 3-48 and also dropped a more difficult return chance offered by Foakes. Fast bowler Meaker (3-61) turned the game on its head by ripping out Bairstow (13), Ballance (32) and Jack Leaning. Bresnan and Waite (38) did their best to repair the damage, but 27 off the final three overs was too much and Bresnan holed out at long-off with seven balls remaining.

The 56ft (17.1m) converted trawler was 6 miles (10 km) west of South Stack when the crew radioed coastguards at 07:00 BST. A pump on board the boat was unable to cope with the water coming in. The RNLI lifeboat crew placed a pump and towed the vessel to Holyhead.

Muir will not be with the Scotland team at next year's event on Australia's Gold Coast because of her veterinary medicine studies. The 24-year-old finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships. The World Indoor Championships in March are "potentially a target". Muir's time of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds was her new outdoor personal best.

Robbie Savage discusses Liverpool's chances of repeating last season's title challenge, their upcoming match against Chelsea, and Steven Gerrard's future with the team. Liverpool is far from the level needed to contend for the title and needs to improve to get in the top four. The team has struggled with transfers, especially up front, and their defense is still weak. Gerrard is still an important player for Liverpool and can remain competitive in the Premier League.

A £45m facility will be built at Sutherland Drive in Kilmarnock. It will house primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school and a childcare centre. East Ayrshire Council will ask permission from the McIlvanney family to name the campus in his honour. The writer was born and educated in Kilmarnock. McIlvanney became an English teacher but changed career in 1975 to write full time. He gained immediate recognition with the publication of his first novel and earned the title of "Godfather of Tartan Noir". The novelist died at his Glasgow home on 5 December.

An area of the town near the swimming pool had been evacuated. An exclusion zone remains in force on the river while experts make safe the sea mine which was spotted on Monday. The evacuation affected three streets, with wider safety advice issued to residents within 500m of the device. There was also an exclusion zone at sea of about half a mile, and small boat owners were told not to sail during the operation. Caledonian MacBrayne reported some disruption to ferry services, affecting sailings from Gourock and Rothesay. The evacuation had been a precautionary measure. It was decided to move the mine to a safer place before dealing with it.

A total of £345m will be invested in 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports. UK Sport has set Team GB a target of winning 51-85 Olympic medals, and 115-162 Paralympic medals in Tokyo. Cycling has had its funding cut by more than £4m to £25.98m. Badminton's funding has been removed. Investment in the five Olympic sports and two Paralympic sports added for Tokyo 2020 is yet to be confirmed. £9m of the £345m total is still to be allocated.

A six-storey, four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks will be built at East Cliff in Bournemouth. The buildings will be built on Grove Road and East Overcliff Drive. The East Cliff Project LLP will demolish Bay View Court, The Cottonwood, and the Ocean View hotels. The council voted seven to three in favor of the development. The council received 246 letters supporting the plans. Forty-nine residents and the Ancient Monuments Society wrote to object to the demolition. English Heritage said the scale of the development would cause "severe harm" to the conservation area.

Pte Matthew Boyd was punched and beaten by Jake Vallely. Vallely will be sentenced on 8 December. Pte Boyd's body was found by police in Brecon. Pte Boyd was attacked outside a bar called The Cellar. Vallely dragged his body from the scene before fleeing. Vallely had been on a seven-hour drinking binge. Vallely's friend Aaeron Evans was cleared of manslaughter.

Andrew Travers left the authority by "mutual agreement" after the error. Voters were initially turned away from all 155 polling stations because their names were missing from the poll list. An independent investigation has been launched. Deputy chief executive John Hooton will take over temporarily. The council's review will conclude by the end of May and the findings will be presented publicly to the General Functions Committee.
Josh Gillies scored a free-kick for Gateshead. Sean Newton scored a set-piece for Wrexham. Ryan Bowman scored a winner for Gateshead. Gateshead won the match 2-1.
The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 measures the social and economic welfare of those over 60 in 96 countries. Norway comes on top and Afghanistan is the worst country, followed by Mozambique.

The network will comprise at least 600 spacecraft, but could eventually encompass more than 2,000. The aim is to deliver broadband links from orbit to every corner of the globe. The project wants every school to have a connection. The first 10 satellites have a deadline to launch in April next year. The establishment of the OneWeb constellation requires the greatest rocket campaign in the history of spaceflight. More than 20 Soyuz vehicles have been booked to throw clusters of 32-36 satellites into a web some 1,200km above the Earth. Airbus believes the OneWeb concept has first-mover advantage. Equity of $1.7bn has already been raised, and talks are ongoing to secure the loans needed to complete the roll-out. OneWeb describes itself as a "truly global company" but it has company registration in the UK's Channel Islands. Airbus and OneWeb have inaugurated the first assembly line in Toulouse, France.

The UK government's spending review placed "unprecedented pressure" on public expenditure north of the border. Scottish ministers would have £390m more in spending available to them next year. The Scottish government argues that its discretionary budget will be 12.5% lower in real terms by 2019-20 than it was in 2010-11. 4.2% of that reduction would come between now and 2019-20. The Scottish government is determined to defend and protect the key priorities that the people of Scotland expect. The Scottish government will have £390m more spending available to it next year, which rises to £750m if you include its own underspend. The stability of the UK economy means the block grant will be almost £30bn.

Campaigners are calling for Changing Places toilets to be made compulsory. These toilets have extra features and more space to meet the needs of people who need help. There are currently 893 Changing Places toilets in the UK. The guidelines have been included in the Building Standards guidelines since 2009 as a recommendation rather than a compulsory requirement.

A group of Italian consumers' organisations made a formal complaint to the European Commission accusing McDonald's of forcing franchisees to pay excessive rents and high fees. McDonald's said it shared risks and rewards with its licensees. The Service Employees International Union (SEIU) and European unions are supporting the formal antitrust complaint. The European Commission said it would now study the submission and has the powers to launch an investigation if it believes the allegations are founded. Franchisees own and operate 73% of McDonald's restaurants in Europe. McDonald's received $9.27bn in revenues from its franchised restaurants worldwide in 2014.

A social media campaign supporting 13-year-old Joshua Martin, from Donaghadee, County Down, began as a hashtag on Facebook and Instagram by Bangor Elim Church after he was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve. A poster with the phrase #prayforjosh appeared in Holywood by the A2 within the last week. The church's senior pastor, Gary Beattie, said he was amazed by how many people have supported Josh and his family so far. A mystery donor paid for the sign and it was erected at Holywood playing fields. There has also been a huge outpouring of support on Twitter for the Bangor Grammar pupil.

The UK military is reorganizing its buildings and resettling regiments. Brecon and Radnorshire Conservative MP Chris Davies condemned the closure of Brecon Barracks, which has been in Brecon since 1805. Cawdor Barracks will shut in 2024, and a storage depot at Sennybridge will close in 2025. A specialist light infantry center will be created at St Athan, Vale of Glamorgan.

The House of Lords released a report looking at the risks and opportunities for the UK fishing industry. The report warns that Britain may have to allow EU-registered boats to fish in UK waters as part of an overall deal. The report also points to the fact that many elements of the CFP should be retained post-Brexit and the UK should ensure that total allowable catches and quotas should continue to be based on scientific advice. Many in the fishing industry still argue that Brexit will bring more opportunities than threats.

Ed Snowden, a former CIA technical worker, revealed himself to be the source of the leaks. The US National Security Agency (NSA) has access to individual chat logs, stored data, voice traffic, file transfers, and social networking data. The US government requested millions of phone records from US company Verizon. Prism enabled "backdoor" access to the servers of nine major technology companies. The US Patriot Act of 2001 gave American authorities new powers over European data.

OpenAI's backers include Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services. OpenAI expects its research to focus on a "positive human impact". Scientists have warned that advances in AI could threaten humanity. OpenAI aims "to advance digital intelligence in the way that is most likely to benefit humanity as a whole, unconstrained by a need to generate financial return". Only a tiny fraction of the $1bn pledged would be spent in the next few years.

L/Bdr Parkinson was injured in a bomb attack in Afghanistan in 2006. He carried the torch on June 26. He has had thousands of Facebook requests, but the site limits friend associations to 5,000 per personal page. He walked with the Olympic torch for nearly half an hour with an assistant. He spends 12 hours a day in the gym and rehab and walks with crutches. He spends the rest of his time raising money for military charities and as patron of Pilgrim Bandits. His mother said the responses had "been phenomenal". Facebook would not comment on the issue but their guidance was that if people were receiving this many requests then they have become a public figure, so should consider having a page instead of a profile. A total of 8,000 people will carry the flame during its 8,000 mile, 70-day journey to the opening ceremony of the Olympic Games in London on 27 July.

In 2011, the poverty rate was 15%, with 46.2 million Americans in poverty. Real median income dropped by 1.5%. The average poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. Income inequality increased by 1.6%. The percentage of Americans lacking health insurance fell to 15.7%. Poverty in the US reached a record high in 2010, at 15.1%.

Buttler moved to the Red Rose from Somerset in 2013 and his new deal ties him to the club until 2019. Buttler has scored England's three fastest ODI centuries. Buttler will return to Lancashire for Friday's T20 Blast home game against Durham.

The decommissioned Type 22 frigates HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham and HMS Cornwall are moored in Portsmouth Harbour. Bidders had until 23 January to register an interest in the former Devonport-based ships. Those who have registered an interest are finalising their bids with viewings set to take place in late February and March. A final decision is not expected until the spring. The government's Disposal Services Authority, which is handling the sale, wants to award at least one of the frigates to a UK ship recycler. The Ministry of Defence has previously said it will "consider all options" for the frigates to ensure "best financial return for the taxpayer". Originally designed as a specialist anti-submarine ship, the Type 22 frigate evolved into a powerful surface combatant. Last year, the aircraft carrier HMS Ark Royal was sold as scrap for Â£3m.

Since 1987, racial and political tensions have caused instability and international isolation. A coup in 1987 overthrew the elected, Indian-dominated coalition. A further coup in 2000 saw the country's first ethnic Indian prime minister, his cabinet and several MPs held hostage. These events harmed the economy and Fiji's international reputation. A bloodless military takeover occurred in 2006. In September 2009, Fiji was suspended from the Commonwealth. In 2012 the government agreed to hold free elections in 2014. Following the elections the Commonwealth re-instated Fiji as a member. Fiji's population is divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians. Fiji relies heavily on the sugar and tourism industries for its foreign exchange. Fiji has been hampered by persistent trade and budget deficits.

Syria is trying to comply with the timetable to destroy its chemical weapons. Syria missed Wednesday's deadline to hand over its entire stockpile. A shipment of weapons came under attack twice on its way from Damascus to the port of Latakia. The US said that so far only about 4% of the stockpile had left the country. Russia has said Damascus should complete the transfer of its chemical weapons to the coast for removal by ship by 1 March. A deadline was set last year for all the weapons to be destroyed by the end of June.

Mukherjee's The Lives Of Others is the favorite to win the Booker Prize. The winner will be announced at London's Guildhall on Tuesday night. The prize is open to all authors writing in English, regardless of nationality. Other authors on the shortlist include Howard Jacobson, Ali Smith, Joshua Ferris, Karen Joy Fowler and Richard Flanagan. The shortlisted authors each receive £2,500 and a specially bound edition of their book. Coverage from this year's ceremony will be on the BBC News Channel from 2130 BST and on BBC Arts.

The Supreme Court will hear arguments about whether to grant an appeal regarding an appeal court ruling lifting a ban on a man being named in the media in England and Wales. An interim injunction will remain in place until the end of the hearing. The Sun on Sunday wants to publish an account of alleged extra-marital activities by the man, who is referred to as PJS. The man argues he has a right to privacy and has taken legal action.

Fosse Park opened in 1989 and was bought in August for £345.5m. Plans are being prepared to improve parking, traffic congestion, and the appearance of units. The new owners had met with the council to clear up "potential planning questions". The new owners want to address parking and congestion issues and improve the quality of the common areas.

The film was due for release in Malaysia on Thursday, but Disney said it was being held for a "review" of its content. The Malaysian Censorship Board (LPF) said on Tuesday it had approved the screening but with "a minor edit concerning a gay moment in the film". A new release date has yet to be announced. The live-action remake was granted a "P13 parental guidance classification". Local cinema chains have been offering refunds for customers who have purchased tickets in advance.

Landlords who let properties to more than three unrelated people need to apply for a licence for a House of Multiple Occupation (HMO). A licence can cost ??1,000, despite facing a fine of up to ??20,000. The authority estimated a total of 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in the area. Nationally, mandatory licensing for HMOs is aimed at houses of three storeys or more and occupied by five or more unrelated people. In Southampton, the licences affect properties in Bargate, Bevois, Portswood, Swaythling (Designation 1 - introduced in 2013) and in Shirley Freemantle, Millbrook, and Bassett (Designation 2 - introduced in 2015). The council said it had so far gained prosecutions against one firm and 13 individuals.

Enda Kenny of Fine Gael and Micheál Martin of Fianna Fáil hope to avoid a second election. Fianna Fáil will facilitate a minority government, but will not support a programme for government. Water charges are one of the main sticking points to reaching agreement. Fine Gael had 50 seats, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23 and the Labour Party got seven following the election. No party was able to form a majority government and TDs have so far failed to elect a taoiseach.

The Sorrento was traveling to Valencia when a fire started and got out of control. Passengers were evacuated to lifeboats and rescued by another ship. At least three people were injured and taken to the hospital by helicopter. The ship was about 27km (17 miles) from Mallorca when the fire broke out on Tuesday afternoon. The reason for the fire was unclear. The passengers and crew boarded one of the ferries, the Puglia. The rescued passengers were on their way back to Palma de Mallorca. The Balearic Islands port authority said The Sorrento may sink. The ferry sent out distress signals at 13:50 local time (11:50 GMT). The captain did not believe it would be necessary to abandon the ship at first but a full evacuation was called for.

38 MPs highlighted people claiming to have voted twice, which is a criminal offense. Individual electoral registers should be better joined up to help identify duplicate entries. A record number of 46.8 million people were registered to vote in the 8 June election. 68.7% of those registered actually voted. There was a surge in applications to register to vote. Concerns over the number of duplicate applications continue to persist. The proportion of duplicate applications is estimated to have ranged between 30% and 70% in different areas. Voting twice in a general election was an offense punishable by an unlimited fine.

Lawrence Phillips, 40, killed himself early on Wednesday. He was a star player at the University of Nebraska and played for the St Louis Rams, Miami Dolphins and San Francisco 49ers until 1999. After his NFL career, Phillips was sent to prison after being convicted of assault. He was serving a term of more than 30 years and had been placed in a cell alone after he was accused of killing his former cellmate. On Tuesday, a judge found that there was enough evidence to try Phillips in the death of Damion Soward, 37.

Private Derby XXX was promoted to lance corporal at an event in Chester marking eight years of the Mercian Regiment. He was awarded his honour by Brigadier Andrew Williams. He received his promotion for "good behaviour". He is the 30th in a line of mascot rams running back to the Indian Mutiny War. The first Private Derby was acquired in 1858 and became the mascot of the Mercian Regiment when it formed in 2007. Lance Corporal Derby XXX joined the regiment in February 2014. He has his own army number, gets paid to buy his rations and takes his holidays during the mating season on the Chatsworth Estate in Derbyshire. Lance Corporal Derby XXX has also helped switch on the Christmas lights in Ashbourne and met Prince William.

Liverpool won 4-3 against Borussia Dortmund. Liverpool moved a step closer to earning a place in the Champions League. Klopp's priority was to "turn doubters into believers". Liverpool needed three goals, leaving Klopp to invoke the spirit of Istanbul and the Champions League Final won from 3-0 down at half-time against AC Milan in 2005. Klopp has imprinted his identity on his new players and Liverpool's fans.

Mr. Davis said the UK government would keep Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland up-to-date about negotiations. Mr. Davis wanted to hold a monthly meeting to share analysis as part of a "two-way information flow" with each of the three nations. Mr. Russell said transparency about UK government plans was needed. The Scottish government will seek to oppose the UK government in the Supreme Court during the appeal.

Thirteen cloned sheep are living on a farm owned by the University of Nottingham. Four of the sheep (Daisy, Debbie, Denise, and Diane) were cloned from the same adult ewe as Dolly the sheep. The sheep are undergoing tests to determine if they age in a normal way and how healthy they are. The tests include joint X-rays and full-body fMRI scans. The results of the study will be published next week.

Shutter Speed beat runner-up Vintage Folly by a length and three quarters. Tasleet took the Duke of York Stakes. Shutter Speed brought a fifth Musidora win for both Gosden and Dettori. Gosden is concerned about the ground for his colt Cracksman in Thursday's Dante Stakes. Shutter Speed will go to France's Oaks. Gosden will rely on Enable and Coronet in the longer Epsom Oaks.

The currency initially slipped against the dollar and euro, but started recovering before falling again. The "volatility index" has hit levels last seen in the 2008 financial crisis. The pound was down 0.2% against the dollar at $1.4226, down 0.6% against the euro at â‚¬1.2605, and weakened by 1% against the Japanese yen to just over 151. Two polls put the Leave camp ahead, while betting firm Betfair said the implied probability of a vote to Remain had fallen to 68.5%. The FTSE 100 ended the day down 1.1% at 6,044.9 points.
The Iron are sixth in the National League, one point and one place outside the play-off spots. Braintree's losing run extended to three games.

From April 2015, councils will be in charge of planning decisions. Councils will be able to accept or reject developments in their own areas. Michael Corr is optimistic about the move. Friends of the Earth warn that a strict code of conduct will have to be rigorously enforced. Some local politicians remain opposed to the move.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot three times and her left back leg had to be amputated. The cat was found by her owner on March 14th and taken to the Scottish SPCA. The Scottish SPCA is urging anyone with information about the incident to contact them. Last year the Scottish government held a consultation on licensing air weapons, but a majority of responders opposed the plan.

Benteke is Liverpool's second most expensive signing on a long-term contract. Liverpool triggered a release clause in Benteke's contract to make the 24-year-old their seventh summer signing. Benteke scored 49 goals in 101 games for Villa after signing from Genk for £7m in 2012. Liverpool struggled for goals last season and manager Brendan Rodgers has added Benteke to revive the Reds' attack. Liverpool have also signed forwards Danny Ings from Burnley and Brazil international Roberto Firmino from Hoffenheim.

The study found no clear evidence of academic improvement for pupils using tablet devices. Tablets are used in 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools. The highest use of tablet computers was within academy schools. Between 2014 and 2016, the number of tablet computers in schools is expected to rise from about 430,000 to almost 900,000. Head teachers reported a positive impact and they help to motivate pupils. A separate study suggested that touch-screen computers were particularly useful in helping boys and poorer pupils to learn to read.

The exhibition Growing Up in the City at the Museum of Liverpool has 25 photographs that capture the life of children over more than 100 years. The photographs span the period from the 1880s to the 1990s. The oldest image dates back to 1887. The exhibition has been put together by Kay Jones, Curator of Urban Community History at the Museum of Liverpool. Growing Up in the City is at the Museum of Liverpool until 25 September.

Anderson, 27, has cancelled his Barrow contract to join their National League rivals. Striker Keating, 21, was recommended to Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams. The Gulls are currently four points above the relegation zone, and have won only one of their last six games.

A 50-year-old woman said she was "lucky to be here" after falling ill at home and looking up her symptoms online. She searched "women's heart attack symptoms", which included sudden nausea and aches, before taking a few aspirin. She visited a cardiologist the next day, who inserted a stent into an artery that was 99 per cent blocked. Her chest began to ache last week and she became nauseous and feverish after helping a woman who was struggling to get out of her car in her Nyack village home, near New York. The type of attack was known as the "widow maker". She did not call the emergency services. She issued a warning to her readers: "Know the symptoms ladies, listen to the voice inside, the one we all so easily ignore, call 911." She recently hosted The Rosie Show on the Oprah Winfrey Network but the daily talk and gameshow was cancelled in March due to low ratings.

Che Labastide-Wellington was at a party in Belvedere Way, Kenton, on Saturday evening. There was a fight with a group of youths who tried to gain entry. Che was stabbed in an alleyway at about 00:30 GMT and pronounced dead about an hour later. A 16-year-old boy was also stabbed and taken to a north London hospital. A man aged 21 has been arrested on suspicion of murder. Two boys aged 15 and 16 were also arrested on suspicion of murder and bailed until mid-December. A third, aged 14, is being held on suspicion of possession of an offensive weapon.

Denmark reorganized how patients were diagnosed by GPs and specialists due to alarming cancer survival statistics. The changes included fast-track diagnosis and treatment routes, diagnosis centers for patients with difficult-to-diagnose symptoms, and "yes-no" centers for patients with minor symptoms. These changes have led to better survival rates.

Powys will issue warning and banning orders against agents acting dishonestly or breaching estate agent laws. Powys won the competitive bidding process to deliver the service in place of the OFT and will receive Â£170,000 a year to carry out the work. People complaining about estate agents will still contact their local authority trading standards department, who will prosecute offenders if necessary, but will refer cases to Powys if they believe parts of the Estate Agents Act have been breached. James Munro from Powys council will lead the new team.

NHS Employers approved a plan to reshape the 1.3 million-strong workforce after advisers said there were extra tasks they could do with more training. A Nuffield Trust review found examples of nurses filling in for hospital doctors and pharmacists for GPs. The report said that as doctors only made up about one in 10 of the workforce much more was needed from other health staff, but the Nuffield Trust admitted money would need to be set aside to ensure it happened.

The Lower Bristol Road in Bath was closed at Rackfield Place outside the First depot after a crash at 03:00 GMT. The A36 road closure was lifted at 14:00 GMT. Investigations are under way into how the collision happened. First said that it would take a few hours for all services to return to normal.

NRW estimated the lagoon would mean 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout dying each year. TLP said the claims had no "clear scientific basis". TLP said that computer modelling carried out by experts on its behalf estimated a "worst case scenario" of the lagoon killing 2% of all species of fish. The Â£1.3bn Swansea tidal lagoon project is being viewed by the firm as a test bed for much larger and more cost effective versions around the coast. UK government ministers are considering the findings of a six-month review of the viability of the scheme, which is yet to be published. Wales' Environment Secretary Lesley Griffiths said the Welsh Government was "very supportive" of the scheme.

Northern Ireland's agri-food industry was announced by Stormont's Enterprise, Trade and Investment (DETI) Minister Arlene Foster. The marketing body will be developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB). The new industry-led agri-food marketing body will provide an opportunity for the Northern Ireland agri-food industry to work together. The body will play a role in providing strategic leadership and direction for the marketing activities of both government and private sector organizations. Stormont's Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill welcomed the announcement. Industry representatives had made it clear that there was a need for better coordination of current marketing activities in Northern Ireland.

On Saturday afternoon, the public is invited to plant thousands of new trees at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley. The project is organized by the Woodland Trust and is one of four new woods being created across the UK. The aim is to plant "millions" of native UK trees to commemorate the millions of people who died during WW1. In Brackfield Wood, the charity plans to plant 40,000 trees in tribute to the estimated 40,000 people from the island of Ireland who lost their lives in the conflict. The charity is providing the saplings for members of the public to plant. Brackfield Wood is about seven miles outside Derry city, just off the Glenshane Road.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award. Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution honor. The accolades were handed out at the start of the North Yorkshire town's annual crime writing festival. Someone Else's Skin is the first in a series of novels featuring Det Insp Marnie Rome. Sara Paretsky was chosen for the outstanding contribution to crime fiction award after her 23-year career writing about VI Warshawski.

In 2016, Santner broke his finger in his second game for the county. He will rejoin the Rapids following June's ICC Trophy in England. In August, Worcestershire signed Australia pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season.

Barry Pring was killed by a speeding car in Kiev in 2008. The coroner recorded a verdict of unlawful killing. His wife, Ganna Ziuzina, tried to claim his assets after his death. His family believe he was killed in a staged hit and run accident. The inquest heard Ms. Ziuzina sold her husband's Range Rover and moved funds from his bank account. The Ukrainian police closed an inquiry into his death, but relaunched it in 2011 as a murder inquiry.

Charlie, of Merseyside, needs to fly back to Seattle, America for experimental treatment unavailable in the UK. He needs more T-Cell Therapy at Seattle Children's Hospital after the last transplant failed. His mother said she was "ecstatic" and "overwhelmed" by the person who paid for his treatment. Charlie has been ill since the age of three. After a third relapse in April there was "no option" left for treatment for him in the UK. The family were left "heartbroken" when the first T-Cell transplant did not work. The news the treatment has been paid for was "completely overwhelming". Charlie's father said they were "extremely grateful" for the generosity of the anonymous donation. The treatment will start as soon as possible.

Apple has implemented a new security measure to prevent third-party software from stealing intimate photos from iCloud. The process introduces an extra step after an account holder types in their username and password. They are required to enter a four-digit code texted to a trusted mobile phone number or sent via Apple's Find My iPhone app. If the code is not entered, access to iCloud is refused. A 14-character recovery key can be used to regain access to the account if a trusted device is lost or stolen. Apple plans to encourage people to turn on two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords.

The "finer points" of a deal which could see Wright buy 20% of the club are yet to be released. Wright will become a club director. Billericay are eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points adrift of a play-off place. Billericay have recently been taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin. The club signed former England international Paul Konchesky, 35, at the start of March.

Mr. Ashley has until March 21st to respond to a letter from Hartlepool MP Iain Wright about the treatment of his workers. The letter reveals Mr. Ashley had invited the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee to a meeting at the company's base in Shirebrook. The committee will be keeping the treatment of low-paid workers and enforcement of the national minimum wage under review. The committee has offered alternative dates for Mr. Ashley to attend, but he has not accepted any. Should he fail to agree to attend, the committee reserves the right to take the matter further. Sports Direct has not responded to the BBC's request for a comment. The company has previously pledged to review worker rights, with oversight by Mr. Ashley.

The report, entitled Putin. War, is based on facts that have already appeared in Russian and foreign media since Crimea was annexed in March 2014 and conflict broke out in eastern Ukraine. The authors say putting the facts together and describing the human and economic cost of the conflict makes a very compelling case for accusing President Vladimir Putin of waging war in Ukraine for his own ends. Mr. Yashin said Russian soldiers and equipment were decisive to securing all major victories claimed by the pro-Russian rebels in Donetsk and Luhansk. Russian spending on the conflict is calculated at 53bn roubles. The opposition accuses President Putin of masterminding and directing the war to boost his failing popularity.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, was found at the Woodhead Tunnels off the A628 in Derbyshire at 11:00 BST on Monday. The 34-year-old from Wath-Upon-Dearn in Rotherham died as a result of head injuries. A 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield and remain in custody.

Carwyn Jones complained that he didn't see the Article 50 letter before it was published. Mrs. May mentioned Wales in the letter. The identity of the powers the UK government wants to see devolved is a mystery.
Two cars were damaged in an incident in the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area of Newry on Friday night. Police were attacked while "carrying out duties".

Mr. Charney was ousted last year because of employee complaints and accusations of misuse of company funds. The board said it did not expect him ever to return to the firm. Mr. Charney's lawyer said many of the statements made were false. The court filing documents evidence of illicit emails written to female employees by the former chief executive, as well as racially derogatory taunts. Mr. Charney "repeatedly engaged in conduct that violated the company's sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policy". American Apparel was granted a restraining order preventing him from making any negative statements in the press about the company and from trying to get board members removed.

The game will be covered on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app. Greece won the previous game 92-64. Three members of the Greek team will be missing at the Copper Box. The game will be Britain's only home game before they compete at FIBA EuroBasket 2017. The game will be followed by a four-team tournament in Poland.

The author was asked to get the new Apple phone for a piece to camera. The author remembered they had been offered an interview with Apple’s marketing chief Phil Schiller. The author asked to look at the iPhone before the interview. The author brandished the iPhone at the camera for the Ten O’Clock News piece. The author defended the reporting on the Newswatch programme. The author now feels grateful to have witnessed a moment in history.

Tests confirmed all of the cats near Victor Avenue, in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, had ingested the toxic substance. Seven-month-old Meereen died on Monday. Three other cats in the area have died in the last seven days, while another cat died two weeks ago. Meereen had consumed antifreeze. RSPCA inspector, Andy Bostock, is appealing for everyone in the area to ensure pesticides and chemicals were stored safely.

There are no demonstrations in Athens even though the Syriza government is poised to agree and implement more austerity and liberalization measures. Greece's resorts are teeming, and Athens airport expects 25 million arrivals this year, up from 21 million. Greek citizens will be curious to learn why Mr. Tsipras is rushing to agree to terms that he and his colleagues eschewed when elected at the turn of the year. Tsipras remains remarkably popular, in spite of conspicuously failing to deliver an end to fiscal austerity. The new bailout will only hold if Tsipras can offer hope of better times ahead.

Kemp, who last played Grant Mitchell in 2006, will return to EastEnders for Barbara's final episodes. Dame Barbara's character will be killed off. Kemp played Grant from 1990-1999 and then again in 2005 and 2006. Grant Mitchell has been one of the soap's most memorable characters in its 30-year history.

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon stalked Alice Ruggles before fatally attacking her last October. Her parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, were told by two Northumbria Police officers that Alice had been killed. Dhillon had become obsessed with the 24-year-old and had stalked her. Dhillon, 26, denied murder but was found guilty and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years. Her parents have set up the Alice Ruggles Trust to make other people aware of the dangers of stalking.

EDF approved funding for the £18bn Hinkley Point project, but the government will "consider carefully" before backing it. Critics have warned of environmental damage, potential escalating costs, and that the plant is being built by foreign governments. One third of the cost is being provided by Chinese investors. Hinkley Point C is expected to provide 7% of the UK's total electricity requirement.

The new divorce form in England and Wales asks for the name of the person the spouse committed adultery with, but there is no obligation to name them. Family lawyers say that naming a third party adds conflict and complexity. The guidance on the form highlights that it is "not normally necessary" to name the person. If the person is named, they become part of the court case and will be sent copies of the paperwork and given a chance to respond. In 2015, adultery was the reason for 12,148 divorces granted in England and Wales.

Ministers are placing too much emphasis on the environment at the expense of trees grown for timber. Britain is the world's third largest importer of wood. At least 16,000 hectares of commercial forest have been lost since 2001 and need to be re-planted to meet needs. The forestry industry is estimated to be worth more than Â£450m a year to the Welsh economy. The Welsh government wants a balance between the environmental, the economic and the social in how forestry is developed. 90 hectares were planted last year but there needed to be 20,000 hectares a year to meet long-term targets set by ministers.

A boy was badly injured after being struck in Coatbridge. Emergency crews were called to the scene on Bank Street near Langloan Primary School at about 16:40. The boy was taken to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital, in Glasgow, where his condition is believed to be serious.

Defence attaché Capt Oleg Kornienko presented Ushakov medals to the men of the Arctic Convoys. The Foreign Office initially did not allow Russia to honour the veterans as it broke the rules on foreign medals. The Russian embassy said the convoys allowed Russian soldiers to defeat the Germans on the Eastern Front. The convoys consisted of vessels which travelled from Britain to northern Russia to resupply the Soviet Union during World War II. Under constant threat of attack by German U-boats and aircraft, the craft also had to deal with severe cold, storms, and ice floes. By May 1945, the Arctic route had claimed 104 merchant and 16 military vessels. More than 3,000 men died during the maritime campaign that Winston Churchill was said to have called the "worst journey in the world". The Russian Embassy wrote to survivors in May 2012 that it intended to award them with the Medal of Ushakov as a symbol of the country's gratitude. The Foreign Office allowed an "exception to the rules" last year and President Vladimir Putin presented the first medals during his visit to London on 16 June 2013. The Ushakov medal is awarded to sailors who have displayed courage in the course of defending Russia or its interests.

HM Inspectorate of Probation found delays in getting offenders to start their work and said too many were let off if they did not attend. Anything from 40 to 300 hours of unpaid work may be given for offences like shoplifting, theft, drug offences, or criminal damage. Some 70,000 offenders were ordered to do unpaid work in 2014. The report outlined 15 recommendations for improvement. The government placed an order for 10,000 orange bibs to be worn by offenders doing unpaid work. The coalition promised to make unpaid work more physical and intense. Inspectors did praise instances of high-quality work. Among its recommendations were that community rehabilitation companies should reduce how often offenders are turned away from work when they have reported on time. The chief inspector of probation called for "urgent remedial action". A Ministry of Justice spokesperson said it wanted "much more effective rehabilitation".

The comedian was called a "hypocrite" because he campaigns for economic and political "revolution" to help poorer people, yet he lives in a luxury home. He was asked about his own accommodation by a TV reporter and called the journalist "a snide", before walking off. The star has been condemned as a hypocrite plenty of times before.

Dr. Venter is a biologist and entrepreneur who turned the effort to map the human genome into a competitive race. He was vilified by the scientific community. He is a wealthy user of Lear Jets and private yachts. In 1987, he realized that he did not need to trax the entire genome to find the active parts. In 1995, he unveiled the first, complete genome of a free-living organism, Haemophilus influenzae. In 2006, he formed the J. Craig Venter Institute to create the world's first synthetic life form.

Four out of five children in England who ate school lunches had tried food at school that they had not tried at home. Half of parents questioned said their children had asked for foods they had eaten at school to be cooked at home. The most popular vegetables were carrots, sweetcorn and peas. Aubergine, chickpeas and spinach were among the least popular. 628 parents had children who ate school lunches. About four in 10 primary school children in England now eat school lunches, slightly more than in secondary schools. More children in Scotland eat school lunches - about 46%.

Morata, 23, joined Juventus in 2014 after four seasons with Real. The terms of his move to Italy included an option for Real to buy him back, with the fee reported to be up to 30m euros (£23m). Morata has scored three times for Spain in France. He scored 27 goals in two years for Juventus, winning two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias. Morata played in back-to-back Champions League finals. The 6ft 3in striker came through the ranks at Real, making his first team debut at 18, and scored 10 goals for the La Liga side.

Wilson rejoined Forest from Celtic for £2.5m in August 2013, but has been without a team since being released in May. The 30-year-old made 51 appearances in his second spell at the City Ground, having spent four seasons at the club prior to signing for Celtic. He has also previously had spells with Preston North End and Notts County.

Tesco, the world's third largest retailer, is selling its loss-making US food chain, Fresh & Easy. Around 4,000 of Fresh & Easy's 5,000 employees are to transfer to the new business. Tesco will loan the new business around Â£80m. Fresh & Easy operates 200 stores across California, Nevada and Arizona and has lost money since opening in 2007. It will cost Tesco Â£150m to dispose of the Fresh & Easy brand. Yucaipa, a Los Angeles based private equity company, is buying the business. In April of this year, Tesco reported its first fall in annual profits for 20 years.
He experienced racial abuse and is now targeting a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics.

In the late 1960s/early 1970s, the ice fields covering Mont Blanc and the surrounding mountains covered some 375 sq km. By the late 2000s, this area had fallen to about 275 sq km. The new French Alps glaciers inventory was produced by Marie Gardent, from the University of Savoie, and colleagues. The only existing glacial inventory from the French Alps was published four decades ago. By 1985-86, glacial coverage had decreased to a value close to 340 sq km, the new survey shows. Since then, the area has been reduced to about 275 sq km in the late 2000s. This represents an average loss of some 26% over the last 40 years. The greatest losses have been seen in the southern sectors. The northern region includes the biggest French glacier of all - La Mer de Glace, which falls over a 1,000m in altitude down Mont Blanc itself. Its area today is just over 30 sq km, a shade smaller than the 31.5 sq km in the late 1960s/early 1970s.

The Scots have won all five qualifiers and host Iceland at Falkirk Stadium on Friday. Iceland is also unbeaten after four wins from four. The outcome of Friday's contest and the return fixture in Reykjavik on 20 September likely to decide who tops the group. Scotland are in pole position to reach next summer's finals in the Netherlands without the need for a play-off. Evans is one of 12 players in the current 20-strong squad who play outside Scotland.

Stuart Campbell was arrested in the west of England on Friday following a complaint from a woman in south London. She made allegations of harassment taking place over a two-year period. Mr. Campbell was released on bail and said it concerned some tweets and insisted they were not threatening. The blogger has been a vocal campaigner for Scottish independence and launched the Wings Over Scotland blog in 2011. Police are investigating an allegation of online harassment. Mr. Campbell has been bailed, pending further inquiries, to a date in mid-September.

Peta wants the Jolly Fisherman mascot replaced with a modern animal-friendly version, suggesting a fish with the slogan "Skegness - A Happy Plaice". The original Jolly Fisherman poster was commissioned in 1908 and has become synonymous with the Lincolnshire resort. Dawn Carr, of Peta, said Jolly "evokes images of cruelty to animals". Skegness's mayor said all suggestions were welcome but did not think there would be much support for Jolly to be axed.

Scotland won against Georgia. The visitors led briefly through Vasil Lobzhanidze's early try, but the Scots raced ahead through Tommy Seymour, a penalty try, Sean Maitland and Stuart Hogg before the break. Hamish Watson extended the lead, battling over soon after half-time. Lobzhanidze bagged a second try, before Hogg finished off a searing counter-attack.

Tries from Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van and Chris Bridge gave Widnes a 14-6 half-time lead. Ah Van, Lloyd White (2) and Joe Mellor tries made it 38-12. Despite three Cas tries in four minutes, Widnes held on. Widnes moved above Wakefield into seventh, while Castleford remain in sixth, one point above the Vikings.

Fawzi al-Odah, 37, was released from the US facility in Cuba after a US review panel concluded he was not a "continuing significant threat". He had been there since 2002 after his arrest in Pakistan on suspicion of links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban, a charge he denies. He boarded a Kuwaiti government plane on Wednesday morning US time. The release came after Guantanamo's Periodic Review Board in July determined "that continued law of war detention of (Mr Odah) does not remain necessary to protect against a continuing significant threat to the security of the United States". He now faces at least a year at a militant rehabilitation centre in Kuwait. He is the first inmate to be freed since May. Mr Odah's release brings down the total number of inmates at the US naval base to 148. The US opened the facility in January 2002, following the 11 September 2001 attacks in America.

Anzac Day commemorates the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces during World War One. Thousands attended the early morning service at Hyde Park Corner and up to 400 people took part in a parade before the wreath-laying at the Cenotaph. A service was also held at Westminster Abbey. The first time Anzac Day was commemorated in the capital was when King George V attended a Westminster Abbey service in 1916, a year after the Anzac landings at Gallipoli. The eight-month campaign on the Gallipoli peninsula in Turkey was one of the bloodiest of the war and the allied operation was an attempt to force the Ottoman empire out of the war.

Clarkson, 30, joined Premiership Well for a second spell in July and could make his St Mirren debut in the Championship against Alloa on Saturday. He scored nine goals at Dundee last season and has featured mainly as a substitute so far this term. Clarkson has made almost 400 senior appearances at club level. His previous teams include Bristol City, Brentford and Bristol Rovers. St Mirren are eighth in the Championship, seven points clear of bottom side Alloa.

The turkey firm was sold to Ranjit Boparan. Guarantees were given that all current agreements will be honored. The current pension arrangements with Bernard Matthews would continue under the new ownership. The new owner wishes to restore Bernard Matthews to its former position as a highly profitable business. This would be achieved by greater investment in the business, cost savings and utilizing the present spare capacity at Bernard Matthews to process chicken and not just turkeys.

The crossing at Cowes would be free until 2 July "in recognition of the problems" and to allow feedback. The council had ordered a review of the project by auditors. The ferry has broken down, run aground and been suspended due to "training issues". Cars have also been damaged getting on and off. Compensation was up for discussion. The council authorised the manufacture of ramp extensions to resolve the problem of vehicles scraping the concrete. Groundings were an issue with seamanship, which had been resolved.

The House of Lords released a report looking at the risks and opportunities for the UK fishing industry. The report warns that Britain may have to allow EU-registered boats to fish in UK waters as part of an overall deal. The report also points to the fact that many elements of the CFP should be retained post-Brexit and the UK should ensure that total allowable catches and quotas should continue to be based on scientific advice. Many in the fishing industry still argue that Brexit will bring more opportunities than threats.

Timothy Geaney admitted taking or permitting images to be taken between April 2004 and February 2014. He was made the subject of a community payback order and put on the sex offenders register earlier this year. He has now been removed from his profession's register following a General Teaching Council Scotland hearing. The panel found him unfit to teach and removed him from the professional register. He was prohibited from applying to re-register for a period of two years.

A fire on March 2nd at a site on Duncan Street caused train service reductions and travel delays. Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited was suspended from accepting waste after the fire. The firm was "broadly compliant" with fire safety law. The Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS) visited the premises nine times in the last 12 months. The fire service raised concerns to the Environment Agency (EA) in February. The EA decided to revoke the environmental permit, which takes effect on August 7th, subject to any appeal. The company is still required to remove all the waste. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

Syria is trying to comply with the timetable to destroy its chemical weapons. Syria missed Wednesday's deadline to hand over its entire stockpile. A shipment of weapons came under attack twice on its way from Damascus to the port of Latakia. The US said that so far only about 4% of the stockpile - 30 tonnes - had left the country. Russia has said Damascus should complete the transfer of its chemical weapons to the coast for removal by ship by 1 March. A deadline was set last year for all the weapons to be destroyed by the end of June. The Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW) has admitted the process has been slowed down by security concerns.

England won at Old Trafford to level the series. England made 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared. Joe Root was named man of the match after scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 off 48 balls in the second. Pakistan were bowled out for 234 on Monday. Pakistan play a two-day tour game against Worcestershire at New Road starting on Friday before the third Test at Edgbaston gets under way on 3 August.

Older People's Commissioner for Wales Sarah Rochira will call on pensioners and their friends and families to hear their experiences of residential care. The evidence will be used to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. The commissioner will be reviewing whether older people living in residential care have a good quality of life by looking at factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships and the care home environment. Her team will also speak to care providers, social care staff and public bodies.

Sheerin, 39, replaces Neil Cooper at Pittodrie. Arbroath were relegated to Scottish League Two after finishing the 2013-14 season bottom of League One. Aberdeen chief executive Duncan Fraser said boss Derek McInnes chose Sheerin after "a comprehensive process". Sheerin played for several Scottish clubs and also featured for Östersunds in Sweden before moving into coaching. He won a Scotland Under-21 cap in the mid-1990s. Sheerin guided the Arbroath to their first national trophy in their history by winning the Scottish Third Division title and promotion in 2011.

Curtis and Paul Williams will take charge of Saturday's match against Bournemouth after Bob Bradley's sacking. Swansea want to appoint their new boss as soon as possible, with ex-Derby manager Paul Clement the first choice. Curtis believes the current Swansea squad is good enough to stay up.

Dr. Venter turned the effort to map the human genome into a competitive race. Dr. Venter turned his attention to another grand project: the creation of a synthetic life form. In 
2006, he formed the J Craig Venter Institute. In 2001, he announced the formation of a commercial company, Celera Genomics. In 1995, he unveiled the first, complete genome of a free-living organism, Haemophilus influenzae.

The Sutton Trust warns that many apprenticeships are low quality and too short compared to other European countries. The Department for Education says apprenticeships are being reformed to "drive up standards". The Association of Colleges said some existing apprenticeships were respected by industry and should be preserved. The report says fewer than 200,000 of the 520,000 apprenticeships starting in England every year are rated at level three. The report cites figures that suggest apprenticeships are offered by just one in five (20%) of employers in England, compared with over half (51%) in Germany. The report calls for apprenticeships to be radically expanded, with up to 300,000 new starts each year. A Department for Education spokeswoman said: "We are already radically reforming apprenticeships to drive up standards so that they are more rigorous and responsive to the needs of employers."

Storey finished more than two minutes ahead of Poland's Anna Harkowska in Nottwil, Switzerland. Storey can win a 17th title when she rides in Saturday's road race. Storey is Britain's most decorated female Paralympian with 22 medals. She has won 11 gold, eight silver and three bronze medals in both cycling and swimming across six Paralympics. She won four golds at the 2012 Games in London and has now won 21 world titles across both sports. Storey began her sporting career in the pool, winning six medals at the 1992 Paralympics before switching to cycling in 2005.

Hereford United has been expelled from the Conference. Chester has been reinstated as a Conference Premier club and Hayes & Yeading will stay in Conference South. The club's debt to their football creditors added up to £148,000. The Conference had originally offered a payment deadline of Thursday, 5 June, which was extended three times, to Friday, 6 June, then again to Saturday, 7 June and for a third time until Thursday, 12 June. Tommy Agombar took over as new Hereford owner on June 3. Hereford failed to meet the June 5 deadline. Hereford was expelled from the Football Conference on June 10. When last season ended, the Bulls faced debts of approximately £225,000. The average attendance for the 2013-14 season at Edgar Street was 1,758.

The former Manchester City man, 30, won 61 caps for England after making his senior debut in 2009. He was a squad member at two World Cups and two European Championships but played just three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner also holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player, picking up 46 caps after making his first appearance in 2004. He scored his first, and only, international goal in England's 5-0 victory over Moldova at the 2014 Fifa World Cup qualifiers.

Christopher Hogwood died at his home in Cambridge following an illness lasting several months. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service to be held at a later date. He worked with many leading orchestras and was considered one of the most influential exponents of the early-music movement. He founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973 and directed the academy across six continents for some 30 years. The AAM made more than 200 CDs. He studied keyboard at Cambridge University. His first positions were as a keyboard player and musicologist with the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields and was a founder member of the Early Music Consort of London. He was the artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society. He was also a tutor at Harvard University, honorary professor of music at the University of Cambridge and a professor-at-large at Cornell University in the US.

A boy from Northern Ireland was removed from mainstream schooling in June because he was not coping. His parents requested a place for him at a special school but are still waiting. In September, the family was told that all the special schools in the South Eastern Education Board area were full. The family has now been told that an extra classroom assistant has been employed at a local special school and the hope is that their son will be able to start there in the next few weeks. The Education Authority said they could not comment on individual cases. The Education Authority was "currently reviewing the profile of need for special school places in Northern Ireland and is endeavouring to ensure that places are available close to where the children reside".

Newport Gwent Dragons are subject to a takeover bid from the Welsh Rugby Union, who see Rodney Parade "as a rugby venue." County have a lease to use the ground until 2023. The WRU's takeover of Newport Gwent Dragons will be put to the vote on Tuesday, 9 May. In 2013 the Exiles agreed a 10-year lease to use the stadium. The WRU have signalled their intention to install an artificial surface which is against Football League rules. County are two points clear of the League Two relegation with two games remaining.
